item.text: In the seventeenth year of the reign of Pekah son of Remaliah, Jotham’s son Ahaz became king over Judah.
Ahaz was twenty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned for sixteen years in Jerusalem. He did not do what pleased the Lord his God, in contrast to his ancestor David.
He followed in the footsteps of the kings of Israel. He passed his son through the fire, a horrible sin practiced by the nations whom the Lord drove out from before the Israelites.
He offered sacrifices and burned incense on the high places, on the hills, and under every green tree.
At that time King Rezin of Syria and King Pekah son of Remaliah of Israel attacked Jerusalem. They besieged Ahaz, but were unable to conquer him.

(At <st data-num="01931" class="">that</st> <st data-num="06256" class="">time</st> <st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="07526" class="">Rezin</st> of <st data-num="0758" class="">Syria</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="07725" class="">recovered</st> <st data-num="0359" class="">Elat</st> for <st data-num="0758" class="">Syria</st>; he <st data-num="05394" class="">drove</st> the <st data-num="03064" class="">Judahites</st> from <st data-num="0359" class="">there</st>.<n id="2" /> <st data-num="0726" class="">Syrians</st><n id="3" /> <st data-num="0935" class="">arrived</st> in <st data-num="0359" class="">Elat</st> and <st data-num="03427" class="">live</st> <st data-num="08033" class="">there</st> <st data-num="05704" class="">to</st> <st data-num="02088" class="">this</st> very <st data-num="03117" class="">day</st>.)

<st data-num="0271" class="">Ahaz</st> <st data-num="07971" class="">sent</st> <st data-num="04397" class="">messengers</st> <st data-num="0413" class="">to</st> <st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="08407" class="">Tiglath-Pileser</st> of <st data-num="0804" class="">Assyria</st>, <st data-num="0559" class="">saying</st>, “<st data-num="0589" class="">I</st> am your <st data-num="05650" class="">servant</st> and your <st data-num="01121" class="">dependent</st>.<n id="1" /> <st data-num="05927" class="">March up</st> and <st data-num="03467" class="">rescue</st> me from the <st data-num="03709" class="">power</st><n id="2" /> of the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="0758" class="">Syria</st> <st data-num="03709" class="">and</st> the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> of <st data-num="03478" class="">Israel</st>, who have <st data-num="06965 05921">attacked</st><n id="3" /> me.”
Then Ahaz took the silver and gold that were in the Lord’s temple and in the treasuries of the royal palace and sent it as tribute to the king of Assyria.
The king of Assyria responded favorably to his request; he attacked Damascus and captured it. He deported the people to Kir and executed Rezin.
When King Ahaz went to meet with King Tiglath-Pileser of Assyria in Damascus, he saw the altar there. King Ahaz sent to Uriah the priest a drawing of the altar and a blueprint for its design.

<st data-num="0223" class="">Uriah</st> the <st data-num="03548" class="">priest</st> <st data-num="01129" class="">built</st> an <st data-num="04196" class="">altar</st> in <st data-num="03605" class="">conformity to</st> the <st data-num="0834" class="">plans</st> <st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="0271" class="">Ahaz</st> had <st data-num="07971" class="">sent</st> from <st data-num="01834" class="">Damascus</st>.<n id="1" /> <st data-num="0223" class="">Uriah</st> the <st data-num="03548" class="">priest</st> <st data-num="03651 06213">finished</st> it <st data-num="05704" class="">before</st> <st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="0271" class="">Ahaz</st> <st data-num="0935">arrived back</st> from <st data-num="01834" class="">Damascus</st>.<n id="2" />

When the <st data-num="04428" class="">king</st> <st data-num="0935" class="">arrived back</st> from <st data-num="01834" class="">Damascus</st> <st data-num="04428" class="">and</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="07200" class="">saw</st> the <st data-num="04196" class="">altar</st>, <st data-num="04428" class="">he</st> <st data-num="07126 05921">approached</st> <st data-num="04196" class="">it</st><n id="2" /> and <st data-num="05927" class="">offered a sacrifice</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">on</st> it.<n id="3" />

He <st data-num="06999" class="">offered</st> his <st data-num="05930" class="">burnt sacrifice</st> and his <st data-num="04503" class="">grain offering</st>. He <st data-num="05258" class="">poured out</st> his <st data-num="05262" class="">libation</st> and <st data-num="02236" class="">sprinkled</st> the <st data-num="01818" class="">blood</st> from <st data-num="0834" class="">his</st> <st data-num="08002" class="">peace offerings</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">on</st> the <st data-num="04196" class="">altar</st>.
He moved the bronze altar that stood in the Lord’s presence from the front of the temple (between the altar and the Lord’s temple) and put it on the north side of the new altar.

<st data-num="04428" class="">King</st> <st data-num="0271" class="">Ahaz</st> <st data-num="06680 0559">ordered</st> <st data-num="0223" class="">Uriah</st> the <st data-num="03548" class="">priest</st>, “<st data-num="05921" class="">On</st> the <st data-num="01419" class="">large</st> <st data-num="04196" class="">altar</st><n id="1" /> <st data-num="06999" class="">offer</st> the <st data-num="01242" class="">morning</st> <st data-num="05930" class="">burnt sacrifice</st>, the <st data-num="06153" class="">evening</st> <st data-num="04503" class="">grain offering</st>, the <st data-num="04428" class="">royal</st> <st data-num="05930" class="">burnt sacrifices</st> and <st data-num="04503" class="">grain offering</st>, the <st data-num="05930" class="">burnt sacrifice</st> for <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="05971" class="">people</st> of the <st data-num="0776" class="">land</st>, their <st data-num="04503" class="">grain offering</st>, and their <st data-num="05262" class="">libations</st>. <st data-num="02236" class="">Sprinkle</st> <st data-num="03605" class="">all</st> the <st data-num="01818" class="">blood</st> of the <st data-num="05930" class="">burnt sacrifice</st> and <st data-num="03605 01818">other</st> <st data-num="02077" class="">sacrifices</st> <st data-num="05921" class="">on</st> it. The <st data-num="05178" class="">bronze</st> <st data-num="04196" class="">altar</st> will <st data-num="01961" class="">be</st> for my personal <st data-num="01239" class="">use</st>.”<n id="2" />
So Uriah the priest did exactly as King Ahaz ordered.
King Ahaz took off the frames of the movable stands, and removed the basins from them. He took “The Sea” down from the bronze bulls that supported it and put it on the stone pavement.
He also removed the Sabbath awning that had been built in the temple and the king’s outer entranceway to the Lord’s temple, on account of the king of Assyria.
The rest of the events of Ahaz’s reign, including his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
Ahaz passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. His son Hezekiah replaced him as king.
